title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: Puerto Rico Bankruptcy Dispute Resolved; T. Rowe Price Strikes Deal for Distressed Debt Investor; Evergrande Averts Default Again
text:
The end of the disagreement between a federal oversight board and Puerto Rico's government averts the threat that a restructuring plan negotiated over four years could be discarded.

Puerto Rico's plan to exit bankruptcy approved by oversight board. The federal board overseeing Puerto Rico's bankruptcy agreed Thursday to drop its opposition to legislation enacted earlier this week authorizing the island to raise new debt needed to complete its debt restructuring plan.

T. Rowe Price to buy debt-investment firm Oak Hill Advisors. Money manager T. Rowe Price Group Inc. agreed to buy Oak Hill Advisors for as much as $4.2 billion to enter the private-debt investing business.

Evergrande averts default again by making second late payment. The real-estate developer avoided default for a second time by making an overdue interest payment on dollar bonds shortly before the end of a 30-day grace period, people familiar with the matter said.

U.S. economy slowed in third quarter on Delta surge, supply crunch. The U.S. economy grew at its slowest pace of the recovery in the third quarter, but economists expect strong consumer demand and an easing pandemic to boost growth in the coming months despite lingering supply constraints.

Bankruptcy

LATAM Airlines granted extension for chapter 11 plan. A bankruptcy court judge said he would grant a final request to extend LATAM Airlines' exclusivity period for structuring its chapter 11 plan to Nov. 26.

Some creditors expressed reservations with a fifth extension, but those objections were resolved after LATAM agreed to engage in formal mediation with those parties, counsel to the airline said.

Retired Judge Allan Gropper was appointed in August to serve as mediator between LATAM's two largest shareholders, Delta Airlines and Qatar Airways, and creditors who assert that the shareholders fraudulently transferred value away from the LATAM estate prior to the airline filing for chapter 11.

—Alexander Saeedy

Bankruptcy administrator seeks formation of J&J talc claimant committee. A bankruptcy administrator overseeing the chapter 11 case of a Johnson & Johnson subsidiary on Thursday asked a judge to appoint an official committee for people alleging talc in the company's products caused cancer or other injuries.

U.S. Bankruptcy Administrator Shelley Abel said in a filing in the U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Charlotte, N.C., that she has received responses from more than 50 parties expressing interest in joining a talc injury committee that would have a role in the bankruptcy case.

J&J undertook a corporate restructuring earlier this month that effectively shifted nearly 40,000 talc injury claims to the Charlotte bankruptcy court.

Ms. Abel previously sought to transfer the bankruptcy to J&J's home state of New Jersey, a request a bankruptcy judge is scheduled to consider next month.

—Jonathan Randles

Eagle Hospitality investors denied more time to appeal. Two investors in bankrupt Eagle Hospitality Real Estate Investment Trust were denied a request to have more time to appeal a ruling ordering them to return $2.4 million to the hotel owner.

On Sept. 14, Judge Christopher Sontchi of the U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del., ordered Taylor Woods and Howard Wu to return coronavirus relief aid to Eagle Hospitality, which sued the pair over the money.

They didn't appeal that decision on a timely basis, by Sept. 28. On Oct. 7 they asked the court for an extension of time to appeal, which Judge Sontchi denied Thursday.

—Becky Yerak

Landus approved to buy Atlantic, Iowa, assets from bankrupt Pipeline Foods. Landus Cooperative received court approval to buy property and a grain storage facility in Atlantic, Iowa, for $7.2 million from bankrupt Pipeline Foods LLC.

The assets, which include concrete storage bins, an electric railcar gate opener and hazard monitoring systems for conveyors, initially got a roughly $4.4 million offer in an auction process that drew Landus and three other serious bidders.

Judge Karen Owens of the U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del., on Thursday called it a successful auction. "I'm glad it turned out better than expected," she said. Farmer-owned Landus is based in Ames, Iowa.

—Becky Yerak

More News

An Amazon facility in North Carolina. The company reported an effective tax rate of 11.8% in 2020, according to a Wall Street Journal analysis.

Who could pay more with a 15% corporate minimum tax? Not just Amazon. Democratic lawmakers are pushing a proposal that would seek to collect more taxes from dozens of large companies such as Amazon. com Inc. that record sizable profits but report little or no tax expense.

Big Number

$1 Billion

Close to the amount that Puerto Rico, over its four years in bankruptcy, had run up in professional fees through July.
